t-5cFjvj8qMAmx7pl4cyIw.text: Shiloh Grill, one of the heart restaurants on Mount Washington, they have a patio and indoor seating for your desired heart and depending on weather. GmlOUEozSHlpkYrx6TTRTQ.text: Growing up, we all had our favorite toy, our favorite comfort food, our blanket we slept with to keep us safe when mom or dad turned the lights off at night. This is my go to restaurant and bar. My 200th review as well.   Cheers was 90's TV show about a bar where everybody knew your name. The Shiloh grill is that bar on Mount Washington. Walk in the greeter knows you, the bartender knows you and so does the kitchen staff, bar back and waiter or waitress. The bar is small (half point deduction) and if you can find a seat you'll get meet some nice bartenders and barbacks who seem to not be able to do enough to make your visit perfect. The seemingly endless drink menu is loaded with unique drinks. I love the blueberry basil lemonade, lemon vodka, home made sours mix, then the bartender crushes fresh basil and blueberries into the glass and pours the vodka and sours over that. Great drink to enjoy on the patio which overlooks Shiloh Street. Great wine selection (Wednesday is Wine Wednesday, glasses of wine 6 Bucks all day) and a rather impressive selection of bottled and tapped micro brews. Being an IPA fan, I'm giddy with excitement when I walk in to see what new IPAs I can enjoy with their great food!   Which brings me to the menu! This is one entertaining menu, seriously you'll giggle at the way each menu item is described. The hummus is off the charts delicious. Creamy and chunky at the same time. Flavored perfectly and served with fresh veggies and warm pita. The Alexander the Greek salad is a lettuce free salad of quinoa, tomato, onion, cucumber, olives and feta cheese, it's a refreshing, light meal, also served with warm pita. The menu is loaded with pub and comfort foods like Mac and Cheese, burgers, steaks , sandwiches and pastas. For dessert you gotta try the homemade chocolate chip cookie baked and served in a cast iron skillet, served with vanilla bean ice cream! Yeah, I know, your mouth is watering.   I love this place if you can find a parking spot (this is where they lose another half star) because their lot is small. If you live on the Mount, walking to the Shiloh might be your best bet.

ij5P1F1M_zNoH5WmP96haA.text: What to say about this place? We randomly ended up here on our very first weekend in Pittsburgh and it's become our go-to chow-down spot. We love it. Our lives are entwined with it--from winning the contest to name their pig mascot--we chose Herbie Hamhock--to making it the reception location for our wedding. The staff is amazing--they feel like friends. The menu is witty and quirky. And the art mixes history (Katherine Soffel's story) with the humorous and the bizarre (Geurnica meets bacon). As for the food, we haven't found a clunker on the menu. The standouts are the hush piggies and the mac and cheese. The hush piggies are everything a good bar appetizer should be. They're deep fried balls of finely grated potato, cheese, and bacon. Dipped in a sriracha aioli, they are enough to make one believe in the existence of a higher power. The mac and cheese is, simply put, the best we've ever had anywhere. Paul likes to add bacon to the mac as a routine, but sometimes, when we're feeling flush, he indulges in the perfectly seasoned medium rare hanger steak. We've tried to get the recipe from numerous servers, but no one has coughed up the goods. Not to be missed, is the bacon cheeseburger, the short rib tacos, and the Pittsburgh salad. The range of alcoholic options is also impressive. K particularly enjoys the pumpkin sangria, when in season, and, when not, she'll happily imbibe the frozen Cosmo (which packs a punch).  Don't hesitate to give this place a shot. In fact, you'll probably see us there.

wrGRW7icDttXgwJfvFdzeA.text: Slacker Chic: It's old hat, dude.   That seems to be Shiloh Grill's theme with its "ironic" bill of fare copy and all too laid-back staff, complete with messy hair and stubble on the gents.   I bring this up because of the lackluster service, but more on that later.   Kay and I came by last night due to traffic troubles as well as curiosity; we wanted to see if Shiloh as in fact superior to nearby Redbeard's. Nuh-huh, man.   The menu features nothing innovative, and that in itself is no crime. If their standard steaks, tacos, wings, sandwiches, and burgers were high-caliber, that would be fine, but for the most part, what we had didn't quite stack up to the ceiling.   The pierogi, which in this case are deep-fried and homemade according to the menu, were more like Mrs. T's than Baba Grabowski's, know what I'm sayin'? The outside was crispy, buttery, onion-laden. The insides were starchy and cheesy. Adequate might be the word I'm searching for, and they were barely so. Again, I got a freezer-section vibe from these particular Polish dough packets. If they are handmade, someone's not trying, and I wouldn't be surprised if they aren't considering the...err...atmosphere? Culture? What am I trying to say? I'm working on that.  My Po Boy Crabcake sandwich is half the price of the crabcake entree, and comes in a bun that doesn't know whether it wants to be a Cibatta, baguette, or English Muffin, and there's nothing wrong with that sort of confusion at all. but sadly enough, it was the best and most interesting component of the sandwich.   The crabcake itself, to my palate, had a tell-tale aftertaste and uniformly cut crab chunks, indicating cryogenic shipments and quickie reheats. Was Swanson or Schwan's in on this hoax? "Grandma Sheila's secret sauce" was a tasteless remoulade that was as irrelevant as the Flowbee. If Grandma Sheila exists, and I doubt she does, she should email my mother for her remoulade and crabcake recipes.   The fries that came with it were dusted with an exotic blend of spices that failed to mask the fact that they were limp, far from crisp, and a complete flop. Unfortunately, they were served in a hefty portion.  A bite of Kay's Bacon Cheeseburger gave me some hope that SG has something going for it. Moist 'n rich, 'tis a pity that burgers aren't all SG sells.   Dessert was an overcooked debacle that took 20 minutes (???) to prepare. Cookies-n-Cream is their dismal take on the chocolate chip cookie sundae. Oh, how it sizzled, so much so that our Gen X'er waiter advised us not to touch the dish, which came on a plate. The bulk of the ice cream melted before our spoons touched a thing. There was canned whipped topping and Hershey's chocolate syrup involved, and in just a few minutes, we had a dairy soup on our hands. At this point, the cookie had been reduced to mealy crumbs.  Slacker Chic: It Bites Like Reality, Bro.   So we were seated outside as per our wishes. However, it was broiling outside sans any shade, the sun pitilessly baking me. I saw our server installing umbrellas into the iron tables and asked him for one. His response went something like this...  "Uh, that was the last one. I think. There might be more in the basement. Uh, I dunno man, I can lend you my shades and baseball cap. Heh."   And he walked away shaking his head, chuckling at our obvious unease.   One would think he that would have at least offered us indoor seating, especially considering the ever swelling, ever obnoxious drunken party that crammed next to us without regard to our comfort or existence. More of them just kept coming and coming and coming, looking for more chairs, bumping into us, sticking their asses in our faces, littering our table with cigarette ash, polluting our ears with profanity, shrill laughter, and talk of feminine hygiene issues and bad sexual encounters. I gathered that they were all co-workers, and if so, I want to know who employs them so I don't ever apply for a job with that organization.   And if our experience wasn't already a hog's lunch, as we were leaving, a barmaid delivered a dripping wet mug of beer to one of the harpies seated next to us. As her hand left the mug, she inadvertently flung mead all over me. Very nice. I might as well have been at a Jimmy Buffet gig. The barmaid never looked my way either nor did she apologize.   The mediocre Redbeard's managed to Hoover even less than Shiloh Grill.   What an upset.

WurLSlkTgk8071cae88pNg.text: Let me say that this is a review only for Sunday brunch buffet.  A and I show up at like 10:30 and decide to sit outside which is beautiful.  Nice deck overlooking the street.  We had Jared as a waiter.  If this review were just about how awesome Jared was, it would get like 10 billion stars.  We often go out for breakfast and generally spend several hours gabbing.  Most waiters don't know what to do with us.  Either they ignore us or hover making it known that we need to move it along.  Jared did neither of those things - he refilled out coffee and waters a billion times.  He asked if we wanted anything and when we said that we were going to take out time, he had no problem.  When we finally did get up to go upstairs for the buffet, we took our purses cause 1. who doesn't take their purse when they have to walk from outside to inside and up stairs and no one will be sitting at their table anymore and 2. it's Mt Washington.  The busboy came and cleared out entire table!  Jared quickly got us new waters, new coffees, new silverware, creamers, sugars, salt and pepper, etc.    The food, however, is where this place was lacking.  If you have a buffet at a busy restaurant on Sunday morning, there are a few things that you need to get right: 1.  HAVE FOOD.  Over half the containers were completely empty!  And when the people would come re-fill, they seemed to only re-fill the ones that already had food in them.  2.  Have mac n cheese.  If you are known for your mac n cheese, which Shiloh is, you should actually have pans and pans pre-made and ready for re-fills.  3.  Have the food HOT.  How on earth was everything flying out of there so fast that most of the stuff was empty, but also nothing was hot - some of it was barely lukewarm.    There were some highlights - the pulled jerk pork was amazing.  No idea what you were supposed to do with it alone, but it was really good.  The stuffed peppers, also an odd choice, were very tasty.  The best in my opinion was the carmelized onion and gruyere quiche.  It was very onion-y, but sadly barely warm at all.

7DVds2RgPCTGETU12luqFQ.text: I took an evening walk around the Mount Washington neighborhood and came across Shiloh Grill. While I relaxed and enjoyed the weather I looked at plates that were being served at other tables to aid the decision making process. The staff was very friendly and not pushy at all.  I started with the Polish Church Basement Pierogies  because, you know, "While in Rome..." I am not an expert on Polish food but they were some of the best I've had. The pasta was soft and buttery and the potato filling, well seasoned.  For an entre I enjoyed the "Eggplant Aubergine". This "healthy-ish" dish will take your tastebuds on a slow and sensual sail on an ocean of flavors. Picture a lasagna made with thinly-sliced fried eggplant instead of noodles, held together by cheese and sauce and topped with... MORE CHEESE! A magnificent dish that will leave you wanting more. Advise: Wear your stretchy pants.

We all decided to forgo the brunch and try build a bowl instead. This is where you will start with a starch listed, add a protein such as chicken, steak, or portobello mushrooms to name a few and then top it off with whatever you want. I opted for the quinoa, topped it with both grilled chicken and portobello mushrooms and took roasted vegetables for my topping. It was indeed very good! My son had a different type of bowl and he thoroughly enjoyed it. My daughter settled for a burger with fries. We liked how they imprinted the bun with their trademark.  They are known for the mac and cheese but none of us could eat that much so we decided to forgo it. The Grill has it's own small lot to park in and is located in Mt. You could also choose from Egg's Benedict,  quiche, waffles, bagels and salmon, cheese, fruit, salad, mac and cheese.....yeah, need I go on? My daughter had the Britney Spears chicken which she loved, and my son enjoyed his burger. The hubby opted for Pierogies and wings, and everything was delicious! Although the menu states that the salad comes with balsalmic vinagarette, it`s actually dressed with their fig vinagarette which is much sweeter than a typical balsamic vinagerette in my opinion. mueYIyLWIf0aiFC9afz4FA.text: The first thing struck me about Shiloh Grill was the menu. Not the options or the size of the menu but the names. They were creative thought out and made me chuckle. If you're on a first date, they would be great ice breaker or way to break the silence.  Service at Shiloh Grill was above average as well. You can tell they care about your dining experience. A great example was one of the servers holding the door open for my friend with a torn ACL when we were leaving. They had our money and could have cared less but went the extra mile which would make me come back.  You can get in & out of Shiloh Grill quickly if you want. Our food & drink orders were promptly taken and brought out to us. There weren't long waits and the restaurant was moderately full.  The food at Shiloh Grill is very good. It's not the greatest food I have ever had, but I would not hesitate to come back. The presentation could use some work. It was a clean plate but I'd like to see it more artfully presented. I would like to see a larger beer list. There was really only one beer to represent each style of brewing you could get.  The chili is spicy, maybe to point of lacking a lot of flavor, but thats what I crave. Too top it off, it was free when checking in. Score! Next time, I'd like to try the calamari as it sounded amazing. The fish tacos were slightly above average. It's nowhere as good as something you'd get in San Diego, but pretty damn good for Pittsburgh.   The Cookies & Cream desert was not original. I actually had the same this in Jackson Hole this past week, but I loved the way it was described. I also like the whipped cream added and little bit of chocolate drizzle. That was a good touch!  All in all, I would recommend Shiloh Grill to someone looking for a quick but solid meal on Mount Washington. It is the best dining experience I've had on Shiloh Street.

dzXmcwJKMXWgA_BCjJEr0g.text: I've heard lots of good things about this brunch. I found it to be a mixed bag. Solid basics (bacon, sausage) and an OK but not that imaginative omelette bar. On the hearty side, the chicken tikka was the highlight -- but again, solid but not that memorable. Salad, fruit and breads really limited. Breads and pastries looked pedestrian (Costco bought?) at best. Overall, this is a notch above three star hotel breakfast -- but far short of a first-class brunch. From selection to presentation, the brunch lacks imagination. My sense was that people came for the booze first, and the brunch was a nice add-on.   Service -- like nearly all service in Pittsburgh -- was just plain bad. Not rude, but definitely not informed or helpful. The table next to us had some extra needs or questions and the staff took on that distinctly Pittsburgh attitude of "we're not here to be bothered." Even owner or manager who walked around never broke a smile or offered a thank you.  When I go to Austin or Miami or even a small town in Ohio, I find restaurant staffs -- and I eat cheap -- genuinely warm, pleasant, helpful. Pittsburgh just doesn't get service....at any price level.

sBUedu3uzICf91XXnATucg.text: After reading some mediocre reviews, I ventured into The Shiloh Grill on Mount Washington with cautious expectations, which were eventually proved wrong.  It was Happy Hour so I looked over their ample drink selections, including a variety of mixed drinks, wines and  their 16 beers on tap. Wanting to stay local, I ordered an East End Cherry Chocolate Stout from one of the friendliest bartenders (Gene) I've met in awhile. He asked me my name and used it throughout the evening, which I thought was a personable gesture. Plus, he was periodically joking with some of the locals, keeping it light and fun for a weeknight.   I struggled over what to order because there were so many selections that sounded wonderful, including their famous and plentiful Mac n Cheese, which two girls were sharing beside me. They didn't finish it. (I found out why later.)  I eventually decided on "Thanksgiving on a Blawnox," a half-pound turkey burger with sage stuffing and a little rosemary aioli. When looking at the side dish options, the Mac N Cheese called out again, so I went with it. Great choice!  The turkey burger was very filling, but the MnC knocked it out da park with spiral pasta covered in delicious cheese almost as thick as paste. I now understand why some people just order this for their meal, even if it registers total calories in the five digits. Seriously, proceed with caution!

dJzCa7uYxWpLqIpCYgpPEg.text: Excellent pub food and the staff has a great attitude; very friendly and helpful. Had burger, gazpacho, Mac and cheese, wings, sparkling wine and beers. Was a great lunch and the small deck is great.

0fShOvnT2nd5ji8ly3LARA.text: I recently met some friends on a Sunday for brunch and Shiloh Grill was our destination.  We didn't get there until after noon but the place was surprisingly empty. qFFmxbQndaLZkgvwHaCjvw.text: Meh. This place was a total let down. Went at 830-9 on a Saturday night. The dining room was dying down for the most part at this point and we were seated right away. GGe5Ty_gSAfFrR87Pr5c1w.text: Armed with a Groupon and already being a fan of the Harris Grill, a friend and I trekked up Mt Washington to visit the Shiloh Grill for the first time.  I was a little disappointed that the menu was almost exactly the same as the Harris Grill, but soon got over it as my generous serving of house sangria was delivered.  I started with a HG favorite bean soup served with crumbled bacon (this is a bisque and is very, very good).  Never have I ordered anything with complete caloric abandon, but was feeling needy and placed an order for Mac & Cheese with Lobster and Crab.  It was pretty fantastic.  Like... crazy end-of-days, make-your-jeans-hate-you fantastic.  I could not even eat half of it - because I knew I wanted the skillet chocolate chip cookie with ice cream.  Um, yes.  I ate it all.    My friend started with the tomato soup and was surprised by the nicely spiced serving (I will definitely try it next time).  She then had the crab cakes, which she also liked very much.    She agreed that the fresh cookie and ice cream was fab and we left feeling full and comforted.  Love their upstairs fireplace!  The service was definitely attentive and on top of everything, even though they were pretty busy.  Wouldn't hesitate to stop again.

G_Agw267Xk4WNCwW_-hhAg.text: We had tasty appetizers - Polish Church Basement Pierogies, Britney Spears (chicken) and Sriracha Deviled Eggs.  The chipotle sauce and a basil pesto were very tasty on the Britney Spears; the chicken was moist and flavorful.  I adore Sriracha and have consumed the sauce en masse since childhood, therefore iIt is likely that I am used to super spicy food and found the Sriracha Deviled Eggs tasty but not *spicy.*  A wonderful surprise was the Polish Church Basement Pierogies - our 3yo daughter loved them as much as we did!  Perfect taste and perfect consistency.  The Polish Church Basement Pierogies pairs very well with Flying Dog Gonzo Imperial Porter.  If a porter isn't in your taste profile, there is a large selection of beer and drinks where anyone can find something great.  I love that Flying Dog Gonzo Imperial Porter is available; this is one of the first porters I learned about, I adore dark beers and I appreciate the connection to Hunter S. Thompson!  That aside, the food:  YES!  The food was scrumptious.  The kids had hamburgers that were actually cooked to medium and not cauterized.  I opted for a vegetarian selection: The Garden Weasel.  This sandwich is a grilled zucchini and a portobello cap paired with roasted red peppers, tomatoes, onion, fresh mozzarella cheese, and basil pesto mayonnaise.  (I held off on the cheese.)  What a fabulous array of flavors!  I would love to go back and try their Jamaican chicken (which will be interesting since I've been a month in Jamaica) and their crab cakes (the ultimate test: my east coast palate).  If any place is up for a test, this one is!  I look forward to making this a usual stop whenever we're in the Mt. Washington area.    Lastly, our table opted in for the basket of bacon.  OMG!  Bacon is a religion at this place, and my kids are pious followers of all things swine.  (As if we weren't already sold!)  It is also fun to read the touristy "haunted restaurant" history of the Shiloh Grill.  Fun factoids and very Americana.

JKZo6i-o8zRIRSPMZA1a5A.text: CM and I had dinner at the Shiloh Grill on the 4th of July after we found that another local restaurant (that shall remain unnamed) that took our reservation was closed for the holiday.  Given that I had a City Dining Card for Shiloh, after confirming that they were open, we headed over to grab a table.  Although all of the tables on the porch were occupied, several tables inside were available, so we were able to be seated right away.  Despite being seated right away, nobody came to take our drink orders until almost 10 min. later, after I made eye contact with a manager.  The waitress who took our drink orders offered the excuse that our waiter had to cover some tables both upstairs and downstairs, which is why he hadn't stopped by yet.  After 5 more minutes, he finally showed up with drinks redundant with the ones that'd already been delivered by someone else.  At that point, we were ready to order, so he took our food order.  Thankfully, the food came out reasonably quickly after that, but we weren't super pleased with the service, given the initial snafu.  Because we visited on the 4th of July, there was a special limited menu, but I was pleased to see that the prices appeared to be unchanged from the norm.  First, CM and I ordered a large mac and cheese to share ($12), which was brought out prior to the entrees per our request.  Despite looking rather dry on the top, the mac and cheese didn't disappoint, and was up to the standards of the mac and cheese we'd received from the Harris Grill in Shadyside.  For my entree, I ordered the Henny Penny spicy chicken sandwich ($9.99), and CM ordered the 4th of July blue plate special ($7.76), which came with two hot dogs, tater tots, and a slice of watermelon, and also got chili sauce on the hot dogs (+ $1).  The sauce on the Henny Penny sandwich was spicier than I expected, but placing the vegetables served on the plate on it helped dampen the heat a bit.  To be honest, the sandwich wasn't my favorite, but I know it's a popular menu item here, so if you enjoy really spicy food, you may like it more than I did.  CM's hot dogs were pretty standard, but the chili was a nice touch, dressing them up a bit.  Our respective sides were mediocre, being of the previously frozen variety, and my fries were disconcertingly limp.  CM also tried to take advantage of the Yelp check in offer of a free bowl of chili (worth $3.75), but after ordering it, we found out that we couldn't combine it with the City Dining Card discount (according to the fine print, this is the case--however, at least one other restaurant has let us double dip on discounts, so YMMV, I guess).  While I felt that the price: food ratio was decent here (total check: $24 after discount), unlike our last experience at Harris Grill, I also felt that our meal here was pretty forgettable, aside from the lackluster service.  (Our waiter even forget the doggie bag we requested for our leftovers.)  Everything about Shiloh Grill, from the menu to the setting to the service, was almost identical to its sister restaurant, the Harris Grill, so your opinion about Harris will transfer to Shiloh pretty well, and vice versa.  As such, my rating would be a by-the-book 3.5 stars (reflecting the PGH citywide average), but the inept service we received merits a decrease to 3.0.

4P4NwsTthxDbre4eKMXQGw.text: I don't think I've ever had so much fun reading a menu! It's pretty entertaining, and made making the perfect dinner choice a difficult one. For me, I needed something hearty, comforting, and of course, satisfying before a night out in the 'burgh! I was a first-timer, and hoping my visit will not be my last. Example, this is how they describe pierogies:   -- POLISH CHURCH BASEMENT PIEROGIES -- High-density dumplings from Poland, carefully assembled by nimble immigrant hands, and slathered in butter 'n onions. Dziadzio and Baci wouldn't steer you wrong. Eat, Najdrozsza, Eat!  For dinner, I chose the Build-a-bowl workshop with tater tots, braised short ribs, and the famous mac-n-chee sauce. Obviously, I was not going the healthy route. It was a Friday night, and I was not in the mood for a salad. Only calories and carbs. When the bowl came over, I wished I had ordered sides. The portion was not enough, and it was more of a "six-spoons-in-and-then-dinner-is-over" type of meal. It came in a size of cereal bowl in case you need to picture it. Now, looking back, I wish I could have ordered some of the pierogies listed above.   Like the food menu, the drink menu is pretty extensive and also an entertaining read. I ordered one of their tasty manhattans, and it was delicious!   I'd come here again, but will have to remember to order more or trying something that has more substance.

9r3_qVYFbrNNoooN4uRx0Q.text: You can't beat the atmosphere and the drinks, but I'm just not crazy about the food. I'll do happy hour because of the discounts, but I just really can't find any dishes that I feel are really worth paying for. The staff and atmosphere really make up for the food and that fact that it's a neighborhood joint keeps us coming back. They put so much effort into the menu and its creativity, but if they spent half of that time sprucing up the quality of the food, it would be a 5 star Yelp Review. We're Mt. Washingtonians, we want them to succeed, but the food is just currently "meh."

P0Evmvn0u0nUlgmRuLY6sg.text: Our group of 11 people--8 adults, two kids (under 10), and one infant had an amazing dinner at the Shiloh Grill on Saturday night. It was unseasonably mild and warm and we made an early dinner reservation, hoping to avoid the dinner rush and not intrude on others with our often-feisty/annoying offspring. I mentioned the kids when I made a reservation and a table was waiting for us upstairs, where we had the full run of the place until about 20 minutes before we left. I can't tell you how much I appreciate that they did that for us so that we didn't have to worry about disturbing other diners. We were catching up with out-of-town relatives, and we were able to do so easily being the only party seated upstairs. When the kids got antsy, we were able to let them roam a bit without worrying.  Our waiter, Trent, was awesome (and deserves a promotion, BTW). He helped us navigate the menu, was extremely attentive, knew to serve the kiddos first, and kept my pregnant self well-hydrated. Everyone in our party seemed very happy with their food choices. The kids loved the SOS (salad-on-a-stick), my husband and father raved about their steak sandwiches, my sister and cousin loved their salmon/quinoa/veggie bowls, and the original mac and cheese I had was awesome.   Prices were very reasonable for Mt. Washington and we all left very full, happy, and excited to return (maybe without the kids next time) :o)  Thanks to everyone there who made our experience a great family night out!

HdsrOZorG39qZeVwZmcvOA.text: Let me begin by saying I used to be a huge fan of this place.   Today after many visits I'm saying those is my last.   In the past year or two has gone downhill. Food is cold, portions have shrunk and some members of the wait staff just don't care.  If you want to try this place, goto their other location (Harris Grill) instead. nPOTMTNALl8XMsCMmW4sVw.text: I've been to Shiloh Grill quite a few times and so far I have never had a bad experience. To start it's a relatively small restaurant just off of Grandview. L9iVBSYQ1pZvBfcGv0k58A.text: Well, this place has pros and cons. A lot of the "pros" have been discussed - nice patio, personable staff, decent food. But I think the cons outweigh them:  It took over an hour before our food came out. Two of us ordered apps (as our meal), one salad, one burger. One of the apps (hummus) was sold out. Okay, order something else - spinach dip. That came out twenty minutes later. Yet everything else came out a good 45 minutes after that. Very strange.  The burger was ordered medium rare. It was delivered medium well, at best.  When the diner who ordered the burger told the server it was overcooked and no, he didn't really want a replacement because he didn't want to wait for it, the manager came out. His "sorry for the sucking" was amusing, and much appreciated.  The spinach dip was way too garlicky, and I don't think I've ever thought ANYTHING was too garlicky. Fried cheese (Arsenal curds, woot!) were delicious, and the Popeye-something salad looked pretty good, too.  I think if Shiloh Grill focused less on being witty and more on service and quality, they could be awesome. But, well, they're not.

Ky17V_AgjZEgUDvq-uB-VA.text: Had one of the best times ever with my husband here. We had taken the incline up to see the view and decided to grab a snack and a drink up there. p1J2lwYf9QcB7_5FcX4JYw.text: I last went to the Shiloh 5 years ago when it was known as the Shiloh Inn, so I assumed it was the same restaurant, but the Shiloh Grille is a much better experience. Gone was the uptightness and in its place was a friendly, neighborhood restaurant. The downstairs is folksy and welcoming, and the upstairs has an elegant dining room. The menu is fun and will keep you busy- every menu item has a whimsical name and description.   I came here on a Sunday for the brunch buffet, and it was awesome. The chef at the omelet station made one of the fluffiest ad best-tasting omelets I've had in Pittsburgh. There was think link sausage, thick bacon. eggs, potatoes, fruit, french toast with accompanying raspberry reduction, and more. I was surprised by the cheesy grits (on a buffet!), and biscuits and sausage gravy, which had sage and other seasonings that made it very flavorful. The best part was that it cost $14 and came with an alcoholic beverage- I had a mimosa, but they also had a bloody mary, greyhound, or a screwdriver. If you're looking for a delicious brunch for a good price, make sure you try the Shiloh Grille.

f2hn-8c9YrXzrGgrU1RmKw.text: i was standing on the lookout on mt. washington and i saw this place and figured i'd stop in for dinner. the weather was shockingly nice for february so we decided to eat outside. the menu is entertaining and diverse. the food came out fairly quickly and was pretty good. the service is fairly quick but they definitely have an issue with bussing tables. the table takes forever to be bussed and by the end of the night somebody in my party had 4 glasses that were all empty. my party had the cookie skillet and the brownie skillet for dessert and it was OK. there was barely any ice cream on it but there was tons of whipped cream which melted very quickly and made the dessert quite messy.

UL6hTwjiveE1ZQhPM6AccA.text: I've always been a fan of Harris Grill and when you're from North of the Burgh, Mt. Washington is a much easier trek than Shadyside so we decided to hit their sister restaurant Shiloh Grill today. So glad we did!   Shiloh is smaller but still just as cute with the same food & drink menu, which I've always loved. They also have a cute deck out front for some dining, drinking & people watching. It was only 50 degrees today but people were sitting out there soaking up some of our scarce sunshine. They also have their own parking lot - bonus!  We realized we'd never ordered Harris's calamari & it's pretty awesome. They are tossed in a sweet & spicy chili sauce that's a bit more heat than sweet and cooked to perfection.   I ordered one of my faves, the Henny Penny chicken sandwich & added bacon to it. I know this place is bacon friendly because Harris has done free bacon Tuesdays for years. I neglected to ask if they also do that at Shiloh. Yummy sandwich on ciabatta with a side of vinaigrette coleslaw with radishes & jalapenos.   My hubby ordered the meatballs & they were so flavorful & perfect. Plus when we got the bill it just listed 'Balls' on there, which made us laugh.   Our Green Flash IPAs were a tad pricey at $7 each but the good news is it's one of our favorites and was on tap. Service at the bar was attentive and fun. Our bartender was getting prepped for Sunday Brunch as she chatted to us & it sounded awesome. We know their drinks are stellar!  Nice to know we can have the advantages of Harris Grill with a closer drive to Mt. Washington to Shiloh Grill. Perhaps a return trip for brunch is in order.

p6aqotCepdoCUVdsCYVuCA.text: This establishment was recommend by our Airbnb hostess, on a trip to Pittsburgh. We took the Incline up Mount Washington, to see the view of the city. Aqip5YeknU6MP4lDAxcJSg.text: We came here the other day for a nice lunch, and it was our first time here so we weren't sure what to expect, but it was AMAZING! I ordered the "Just Damn Hot" Buffalo wings with celery sticks and they were truthfully the best wings I've ever had. They weren't smothered in sauce but they weren't lacking any of it either. The presentation was lovely, and they have seriously delicious ranch dressing. I also ordered some fries and they were perfectly seasoned, not too much, not too little! My date ordered the "Rick & Morty Szechuan Wubba Lubba Dub Dub" wings and he loved them too! They tasted delicious too and came with a nice presentation of greens and celery sticks. You have the ability to pick a wing type, a sauce, and a dip, which is awesome and allows you to pick some really fun combos! The atmosphere indoors was soothing, hip, and fresh, and they added lots of Pittsburgh personality indoors and out. The outdoor seating area is very nice, with umbrellas to give you shade and a lovely view of Mt. Washington. Our waitress was incredible. She was so polite and upbeat, and never let us wait long for anything. I wish I knew her name to personally thank her, but she was one of the best waitresses I've ever had. The manager was very courteous and supported his staff very well, which was great to see! It's clear that the team gets along well, which only strengthens the enjoyment of all that Shiloh Grill has to offer. We had arrived around 2pm, and it was not horribly crowded like I thought it might be. It was very pleasant. Their bar area looked great and they have a large selection of drinks. We can't wait to return here soon, this is such a great spot and the staff should be so proud of themselves!

Ir5sTnK_i_hjvoswicxdlA.text: Shiloh Grill is that cool, unassuming sibling we all pretend to have not known of in the Pittsburgh area.  Yes, it is True, Shiloh's sibling restaurant is that place in Shadyside called Harris Grill.  Yes, there are similarities between the two of them, but this place definitely stands on its own two feet.  From the moment you spot Shiloh you think, "Nah, this can't be the place...I mean, it looks like somebody's house with a nice deck on it."  I did this myself, drove right past it and had to backtrack (we all know how hard that is to do on Mt. Washington).  But I believe that is what gives this place the charm it deserves.  It looks weathered and beaten, but in actuality it is the most welcoming spot on the Mount.  Inside gives you the same vibe, that vibe where you feel like you are inside somebody's house and are just in time to start enjoying the house party.  You are warmly greeted by the host/hostess at the door and guided to where you are to be within seconds.    The most recent visit I had here was for a birthday party.  This is quite possibly the best way to sample a wide variety of their food without having to order one of everything on the menu.  The standout star of the spread they had for the party was the pierogis.  Perfectly combined potato masterpieces that, with a dollop of sour cream, made this belly smile.  The drinks were perfect as well.  I stuck to a margarita all night, no salt and on the rocks.  I know I am using perfect in this review often, but that margarita was exactly that; perfect.  When the check came for the drinks (I combined mine with a friend) it didn't hit the pocket book too hard which was a nice surprise.  The servers here were spot on and pleasant as can be to work with.  They came around often to check on us and see if any of us needed a refill.  They never missed a beat and that made things run very smoothly for us.    If reviews had to be a one word summary, PERFECT would be the word to use for Shiloh.    Hey, guess what, this is my 800th review!  PERFECT!!!

oad2oOcpb3HojhgkQlyOqQ.text: I'm so glad the fried cheese curds are back! Praise to the cheese gods!   Shiloh Grill is always a solidly good meal. Some of my favorite dishes include: fried cheese curds (see above), crab cakes mcardle (who'da thunk, but yea they are delicious), all tacos on menu, and the arugula steak salad. The chili and mac & cheese are also delightful side choices.  Fun drink selection, too. Their "Happy Ending" singlehandedly got me through grad school.   The staff is always friendly and courteous and sometimes downright lovely.   That being said, there always seems to be at least one thing wrong with either mine or my husband's order (missing components, missing bacon, stray calamari sneaking it's way in with the cheese curds, bringing wrong drink orders, etc) Nothing that can't be forgiven and overshadowed by the yummy food.   I'm also not a fan of their brunch buffet. I know I'm in the minority with this one, but their waffles seriously need to step up their game. Also, everything always tastes like it's been sitting out. DEOsU-ZQiQuJGMC7tzP5fw.text: As a Mount Wash native for 5+ years, Shiloh was my go to spot. I only remembered to check-in via Yelp twice but I can assure you, I have been to Shiloh hundreds of times.   The great: Brunch, brunch and more brunch'n! AYCE buffet that includes an omelet bar, skillet potatoes with onions, scrambled eggs, sausage links, BACON, biscuits with spicy sausage gravy, waffles, cereal, muffins, two types of salads that vary depending on the Sunday you go, lunch type food that also varies but usually includes broccoli, their famous mac & cheese, jerk chicken, chili and a full spread of smoked salmon, capers, lettuce, tomato, onion, regular and dill cream cheese and bagels. Super NOMS! The brunch price of $17 also includes a boozy beverage! Frozen mimosa, greyhound, bloody mary or screwdriver. The frozen mimosa and bloody mary are my favorites.  Also great- Totchos on their regular menu. Imagine nachos....over fresh tots instead of corn chips. YES, they exist.   The good- The staff!! In my 5+ years of going to Shiloh, I have only had poor service once or twice. The bartender turnover isn't as quick as servers so they get to know their regulars and that makes for excellent service. Their regular menu that includes items that rotate or are added seasonally is a treat. My favorite- The roasted vegetable salad or just as a side. I don't know what Shiloh adds to this delectable dish but even the strongest of carnivores will fall deeply in love with these veggies. The drink menu is also on par with the food. Seasonal drinks and refreshing cocktails. Both menus are extremely well written. Sit back and enjoy them like a good, hilarious novel before placing your order. You won't regret it.   Also good- Happy Hour (get a frozen cosmo) and nightly specials. Tuesday is bacon night. Free baskets of bacon at the bar after 7pm. Enough said.  Just okay- hard cider selection. If nothing is on tap, Shiloh only has Strongbow in a bottle. Weak :( I also wish their Spring hours started earlier. They are only open for lunch during the Spring and summer.  Bad- Nothing, nada, loss for words. You get the idea. Head over to Shiloh for HH, dinner, BRUNCH, or late night. It will not disappoint!

jwwEcMFXqS3elVVaaF5_jw.text: Now, I might be a little biased... having lived in Mt. Washington for so long I was at the Shiloh almost weekly. 6mBiFykwDNQtf-TvjdXm2g.text: The Shiloh is exactly where you want to be after being in the snow preparing for a friend's 'biggest moment of his life.' UWB2Cb6hkb6E0r3GNYi6Xw.text: When I first heard I was going to the Shiloh Grill, I had images of men led by Ulysses S. Grant with Grizzly Adams beards chomping into hardtack along the Tennessee River. Post visit, I can confidently report that the Shiloh Grill seems to be an easy going hangout where locals might go to enjoy friendly service and decent food.   So leave your Enfields at camp. I'm sure even you will be welcome here.  The restaurant is only a short walk from the Monongahela incline, so it should be on the radar of tourists who are taking in the view of Pittsburgh from atop Mt. Washington. The menu is a cleverly written culinary compendium full of local references interspersed with lascivious overtones.   But it's all in a SpongeBob SquarePants kind of way, so relax.    The building is of the type that belongs among popular seaside destinations. Wood shingles, an upraised deck and an inviting bar were all reminiscent of time well spent on Cape Cod. And as a New Englander, it struck me as a tad out of place, but it still seems to work - unlike the fireplaces, which are totally for show.  There's supposedly an element of the supernatural entwined in the building's history, but I'll let the natives speak to the veracity of Pittsburgh's ghostly lore.   My GF and I arrived at the Shiloh Grill about an hour before a family reunion of sorts. Like good bar flies, we spent the hour at the watering hole, chatting with our amiable bartender, who was not only a discerning beer enthusiast, but was also skilled in the fine art of mixology.   We were seated upstairs as the appointed hour neared. And since we had spent our afternoon shopping, among the wares we brought into the restaurant were a few bottles of Bordeaux.  Well, maybe more than a few.  When we were seated, our waiter charged us a nominal cork fee, so we were able to enjoy our own vino and were not beholden to the limited wine menu. Now onto the food.
